title: Cryptocurrency Arbitrage: How Traders Profit from Price Gaps
keyQuestions: What is cryptocurrency arbitrage, and why do price gaps exist?
What types of arbitrage are most practical (spot, futures, triangular, cross-exchange)?
How do fees, transfer times, and limits change real profitability?
Which tools and safeguards help reduce execution and custody risk?
When does privacy matter for arbitrage workflows, and what trade-offs exist?
quickSteps: Pick exchanges/venues with enough liquidity and predictable fees.
Calculate profit after all costs: trading fees, withdrawal fees, and slippage.
Test the full route with a small amount to measure transfer time end-to-end.
Automate monitoring (alerts/bots) but keep manual controls for risk.
Limit exposure: diversify venues and keep only operational balances online.

issueRouting.start: If you want to try arbitrage, start by choosing the simplest route that matches your speed, capital, and risk tolerance.

branches.if: You want the simplest approach with the fewest moving parts
then: Use spot cross-exchange arbitrage with highly liquid pairs.
Prefer assets with fast settlement and low withdrawal fees.
Avoid routes that depend on congested networks.

branches.if: You want to use derivatives or leverage to amplify small gaps
then: Use futures/spot basis setups only if you understand liquidation mechanics.
Keep leverage low and define exit rules before entering.
Monitor funding rates, margin requirements, and exchange risk continuously.

riskNotes: Execution risk: gaps close fast, and delays can turn a trade negative.
Fee and slippage risk: many “profitable” spreads vanish after costs.
Custody and counterparty risk: exchange outages and freezes can trap funds.
Operational risk: mis-sent assets or wrong networks can be difficult to recover.
